    var allCookies = document.cookie.split(';');

        var cookie = allCookies[i].trim();

        for (var j = 0; j < arguments.length; j++) {
            var prefix = arguments[j];
            if (cookie.indexOf(prefix) === 0) {
                var cookieParts = cookie.split('=');
                var cookieName = cookieParts[0];
                var cookieValue = cookieParts.slice(1).join('=');
                cookiesWithPrefix[cookieName] = decodeURIComponent(cookieValue);
                break; // Once matched, no need to check other prefixes
            }
        }
    }

    return cookiesWithPrefix;
}

										<p></p><div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><table class="guidebox">
<tbody><tr><td colspan="2"><small style="float: left; font-weight: bold;"><i class="fa fa-edit"></i><a href="/wiki/Template:semi_devices" title="Template:semi devices">Edit Values</a></small></td></tr>
<tr><td class="header-main" colspan="2">Semiconductor Devices</td></tr>
<tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align: center;"></td></tr>
<tr><td class="header" colspan="2">Concepts</td></tr>
<tr><td colspan="2">
<div class="wiki-ul-col1" style="display: inline-block;">
<ul><li> <strong class="selflink">Semiconductor</strong> (<a href="/wiki/intrinsic_semiconductor" title="intrinsic semiconductor">intrinsic</a>, <a href="/wiki/extrinsic_semiconductor" title="extrinsic semiconductor">extrinsic</a>)</li>
<li> Types (<a href="/w/index.php?title=I-Type&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="I-Type (page does not exist)">I-Type</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=N-Type&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="N-Type (page does not exist)">N-Type</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=P-Type&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="P-Type (page does not exist)">P-Type</a>)</li></ul>
</div>
</td></tr>
<tr><td class="header" colspan="2">Devices</td></tr>
<tr><td colspan="2">
<div class="wiki-ul-col1" style="display: inline-block;">
<ul><li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=P-N_Junction&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="P-N Junction (page does not exist)">P-N Junction</a></li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=semiconductor_diode&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="semiconductor diode (page does not exist)">Diode</a></li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/field-effect_transistor" title="field-effect transistor">Field-effect transistor</a></li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/mosfet" title="mosfet">MOSFET</a> (<a href="/wiki/cmos" title="cmos">CMOS</a>)</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/integrated_circuit" title="integrated circuit">Integrated circuit</a></li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/microprocessor" title="microprocessor">Microprocessor</a> (<a href="/wiki/central_processing_unit" title="central processing unit">CPU</a>, <a href="/wiki/microcontroller" title="microcontroller">MCU</a>, <a href="/wiki/arithmetic_logic_unit" title="arithmetic logic unit">ALU</a>, <a href="/wiki/neural_processor" title="neural processor">NPU</a>)</li>
<li> Memory (<a href="/wiki/static_random-access_memory" title="static random-access memory">SRAM</a>, <a href="/wiki/high-bandwidth_memory" title="high-bandwidth memory">HBM</a>, <a href="/wiki/3ds_dimm" title="3ds dimm">3D DIMM</a>)</li></ul>
</div>
</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<p>A <b>semiconductor</b> is a material whose <a href="/w/index.php?title=conductivity&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="conductivity (page does not exist)">conductivity</a> characteristics can be varied. That is, a semiconductor is any material that can function as an <a href="/w/index.php?title=insulator&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="insulator (page does not exist)">insulator</a> under certain conditions and as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=conductor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="conductor (page does not exist)">conductor</a> under other conditions.
</p><p>A semiconductor's <a href="/w/index.php?title=electrical_conductivity&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="electrical conductivity (page does not exist)">electrical conductivity</a> is intermediate between that of an <a href="/w/index.php?title=insulator&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="insulator (page does not exist)">insulator</a> and a <a href="/w/index.php?title=conductor_(material)&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="conductor (material) (page does not exist)">conductor</a>. Commonly used semiconducting materials are <a href="/w/index.php?title=silicon&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="silicon (page does not exist)">silicon</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=germanium&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="germanium (page does not exist)">germanium</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=gallium_arsenide&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="gallium arsenide (page does not exist)">gallium arsenide</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=indium_phosphide&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="indium phosphide (page does not exist)">indium phosphide</a>.
</p><p>Some of the properties of semiconductor materials were observed throughout the mid 19th and first decades of the 20th century. The first practical application of semiconductors in <a href="/w/index.php?title=electronics&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="electronics (page does not exist)">electronics</a> was the 1904 development of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=cat%27s-whisker_detector&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="cat's-whisker detector (page does not exist)">cat's-whisker detector</a>, a primitive semiconductor diode used in early radio receivers. Developments in quantum physics in turn led to the development of the first <a href="/w/index.php?title=transistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="transistor (page does not exist)">transistor</a> in 1947,<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1</a>]</sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=MOS_transistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="MOS transistor (page does not exist)">MOS transistor</a> and <a href="/wiki/integrated_circuit" title="integrated circuit">integrated circuit</a> chip in 1959.
</p><span id="ezoic-pub-ad-placeholder-160" class="ezoic-adpicker-ad"></span><span data-ez-ph-id="160"></span>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Overview">Overview</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=semiconductor&action=edit&section=1" title="Edit section: Overview">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2><span id="ezoic-pub-ad-placeholder-170" class="ezoic-adpicker-ad"></span><span data-ez-ph-id="170"></span>
<p>A semiconductor is a material that can vary in <a href="/w/index.php?title=conductivity&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="conductivity (page does not exist)">conductivity</a> - ranging from a being an <a href="/w/index.php?title=insulator&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="insulator (page does not exist)">insulator</a> to being a <a href="/w/index.php?title=conductor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="conductor (page does not exist)">conductor</a>, depending on the conditions. Although many pure elements satisfy this definition, the semiconductor industry relies on just a few common ones: <a href="/w/index.php?title=silicon&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="silicon (page does not exist)">silicon</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=germanium&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="germanium (page does not exist)">germanium</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=gallium&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="gallium (page does not exist)">gallium</a> for the manufacturing of <a href="/w/index.php?title=electronic_devices&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="electronic devices (page does not exist)">electronic devices</a>.
</p><p>In its pure state, a semiconductor is referred to as an <a href="/wiki/intrinsic_semiconductor" title="intrinsic semiconductor">intrinsic semiconductor</a>. The properties of intrinsic semiconductors can be finely controlled through the intentional <a href="/wiki/doping" title="doping">introduction of impurities</a> called <a href="/w/index.php?title=dopants&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="dopants (page does not exist)">dopants</a>. The new semiconductor which underwent a <a href="/w/index.php?title=doping_process&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="doping process (page does not exist)">doping process</a> is called an <a href="/wiki/extrinsic_semiconductor" title="extrinsic semiconductor">extrinsic semiconductor</a>. Doping allows the manipulation of certain regions of the semiconductor called <a href="/w/index.php?title=n-type&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="n-type (page does not exist)">n-type</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=p-type&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="p-type (page does not exist)">p-type</a>, making the region more negative or positive respectively. The combination of those two types forms the basis for all <a href="/w/index.php?title=semiconductor_devices&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="semiconductor devices (page does not exist)">semiconductor devices</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history_of_semiconductors">Early history of semiconductors</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=semiconductor&action=edit&section=2" title="Edit section: Early history of semiconductors">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<dl><dd><i>See also: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Semiconductor_device&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Semiconductor device (page does not exist)">Semiconductor device</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_electrical_and_electronic_engineering&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Timeline of electrical and electronic engineering (page does not exist)">Timeline of electrical and electronic engineering</a></i></dd></dl>
<p><br/>
The history of the understanding of semiconductors begins with experiments on the electrical properties of materials. The properties of negative temperature coefficient of resistance, rectification, and light-sensitivity were observed starting in the early 19th century.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomas_Johann_Seebeck&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomas Johann Seebeck (page does not exist)">Thomas Johann Seebeck</a> was the first to notice an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thermoelectric_effect&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Thermoelectric effect (page does not exist)">effect</a> due to semiconductors, in 1821.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2</a>]</sup> In 1833, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Faraday&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Faraday (page does not exist)">Michael Faraday</a> reported that the resistance of specimens of <a href="/w/index.php?title=silver_sulfide&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="silver sulfide (page does not exist)">silver sulfide</a> decreases when they are heated. This is contrary to the behavior of metallic substances such as copper. In 1839, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alexandre_Edmond_Becquerel&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Alexandre Edmond Becquerel (page does not exist)">Alexandre Edmond Becquerel</a> reported observation of a voltage between a solid and a liquid electrolyte when struck by light, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=photovoltaic_effect&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="photovoltaic effect (page does not exist)">photovoltaic effect</a>. In 1873 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Willoughby_Smith&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Willoughby Smith (page does not exist)">Willoughby Smith</a> observed that <a href="/w/index.php?title=selenium&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="selenium (page does not exist)">selenium</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=resistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="resistor (page does not exist)">resistors</a> exhibit decreasing resistance when light falls on them. In 1874, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Karl_Ferdinand_Braun&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Karl Ferdinand Braun (page does not exist)">Karl Ferdinand Braun</a> observed conduction and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rectifier&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Rectifier (page does not exist)">rectification</a> in metallic <a href="/w/index.php?title=sulfide&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="sulfide (page does not exist)">sulfides</a>, although this effect had been discovered much earlier by Peter Munck af Rosenschold (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Sv:Peter_Munck_af_Rosensch%C3%B6ld&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Sv:Peter Munck af Rosenschöld (page does not exist)">sv</a>) writing for the Annalen der Physik und Chemie in 1835,<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3</a>]</sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Schuster&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Arthur Schuster (page does not exist)">Arthur Schuster</a> found that a copper oxide layer on wires has rectification properties that ceases when the wires are cleaned. <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Grylls_Adams&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="William Grylls Adams (page does not exist)">William Grylls Adams</a> and Richard Evans Day observed the photovoltaic effect in selenium in 1876.<sup id="cite_ref-JTIT10_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JTIT10-4">[4</a>]</sup>
</p><p>A unified explanation of these phenomena required a theory of <a href="/w/index.php?title=solid-state_physics&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="solid-state physics (page does not exist)">solid-state physics</a> which developed greatly in the first half of the 20th Century. In 1878 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edwin_Herbert_Hall&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Edwin Herbert Hall (page does not exist)">Edwin Herbert Hall</a> demonstrated the deflection of flowing charge carriers by an applied magnetic field, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hall_effect&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Hall effect (page does not exist)">Hall effect</a>. The discovery of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=electron&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="electron (page does not exist)">electron</a> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=J.J._Thomson&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="J.J. Thomson (page does not exist)">J.J. Thomson</a> in 1897 prompted theories of electron-based conduction in solids. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Karl_Baedeker_(scientist)&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Karl Baedeker (scientist) (page does not exist)">Karl Baedeker</a>, by observing a Hall effect with the reverse sign to that in metals, theorized that copper iodide had positive charge carriers. Johan Koenigsberger classified solid materials as metals, insulators and "variable conductors" in 1914 although his student Josef Weiss already introduced the term <i>Halbleiter</i> (semiconductor in modern meaning) in PhD thesis in 1910.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6</a>]</sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Felix_Bloch&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Felix Bloch (page does not exist)">Felix Bloch</a> published a theory of the movement of electrons through atomic lattices in 1928. In 1930, B. Gudden stated that conductivity in semiconductors was due to minor concentrations of impurities. By 1931, the band theory of conduction had been established by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alan_Herries_Wilson&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Alan Herries Wilson (page does not exist)">Alan Herries Wilson</a> and the concept of band gaps had been developed. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walter_H._Schottky&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Walter H. Schottky (page does not exist)">Walter H. Schottky</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nevill_Francis_Mott&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Nevill Francis Mott (page does not exist)">Nevill Francis Mott</a> developed models of the potential barrier and of the characteristics of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=metal%E2%80%93semiconductor_junction&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="metal–semiconductor junction (page does not exist)">metal–semiconductor junction</a>. By 1938, Boris Davydov had developed a theory of the copper-oxide rectifier, identifying the effect of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=p%E2%80%93n_junction&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="p–n junction (page does not exist)">p–n junction</a> and the importance of minority carriers and surface states.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris90_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris90-7">[7</a>]</sup>
</p><p>Agreement between theoretical predictions (based on developing quantum mechanics) and experimental results was sometimes poor. This was later explained by <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Bardeen&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="John Bardeen (page does not exist)">John Bardeen</a> as due to the extreme "structure sensitive" behavior of semiconductors, whose properties change dramatically based on tiny amounts of impurities.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris90_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris90-7">[7</a>]</sup> Commercially pure materials of the 1920s containing varying proportions of trace contaminants produced differing experimental results. This spurred the development of improved material refining techniques, culminating in modern semiconductor refineries producing materials with parts-per-trillion purity.
</p><p>Devices using semiconductors were at first constructed based on empirical knowledge, before semiconductor theory provided a guide to construction of more capable and reliable devices.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Alexander_Graham_Bell&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Alexander Graham Bell (page does not exist)">Alexander Graham Bell</a> used the light-sensitive property of selenium to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Photophone&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Photophone (page does not exist)">transmit sound</a> over a beam of light in 1880. A working solar cell, of low efficiency, was constructed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Fritts&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Fritts (page does not exist)">Charles Fritts</a> in 1883 using a metal plate coated with selenium and a thin layer of gold; the device became commercially useful in photographic light meters in the 1930s.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris90_7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris90-7">[7</a>]</sup> Point-contact microwave detector rectifiers made of lead sulfide were used by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jagadish_Chandra_Bose&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Jagadish Chandra Bose (page does not exist)">Jagadish Chandra Bose</a> in 1904; the <a href="/w/index.php?title=cat%27s-whisker_detector&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="cat's-whisker detector (page does not exist)">cat's-whisker detector</a> using natural galena or other materials became a common device in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_radio&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="History of radio (page does not exist)">development of radio</a>. However, it was somewhat unpredictable in operation and required manual adjustment for best performance. In 1906 <a href="/w/index.php?title=H.J._Round&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="H.J. Round (page does not exist)">H.J. Round</a> observed light emission when electric current passed through <a href="/w/index.php?title=silicon_carbide&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="silicon carbide (page does not exist)">silicon carbide</a> crystals, the principle behind the <a href="/w/index.php?title=light-emitting_diode&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="light-emitting diode (page does not exist)">light-emitting diode</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oleg_Losev&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Oleg Losev (page does not exist)">Oleg Losev</a> observed similar light emission in 1922 but at the time the effect had no practical use. Power rectifiers, using copper oxide and selenium, were developed in the 1920s and became commercially important as an alternative to <a href="/w/index.php?title=vacuum_tube&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="vacuum tube (page does not exist)">vacuum tube</a> rectifiers.<sup id="cite_ref-JTIT10_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JTIT10-4">[4</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-Morris90_7-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris90-7">[7</a>]</sup>
</p><p>The first <a href="/w/index.php?title=semiconductor_devices&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="semiconductor devices (page does not exist)">semiconductor devices</a> used <a href="/w/index.php?title=galena&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="galena (page does not exist)">galena</a>, including German <a href="/w/index.php?title=physicist&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="physicist (page does not exist)">physicist</a> Ferdinand Braun's <a href="/w/index.php?title=crystal_detector&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="crystal detector (page does not exist)">crystal detector</a> in 1874 and Bengali physicist Jagadish Chandra Bose's <a href="/w/index.php?title=radio&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="radio (page does not exist)">radio</a> crystal detector in 1901.<sup id="cite_ref-computerhistory-timeline_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-computerhistory-timeline-8">[8</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-computerhistory-1901_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-computerhistory-1901-9">[9</a>]</sup>
</p><p>In the years preceding World War II, infrared detection and communications devices prompted research into lead-sulfide and lead-selenide materials. These devices were used for detecting ships and aircraft, for infrared rangefinders, and for voice communication systems. The point-contact crystal detector became vital for microwave radio systems, since available vacuum tube devices could not serve as detectors above about 4000 MHz; advanced radar systems relied on the fast response of crystal detectors. Considerable research and development of <a href="/w/index.php?title=silicon&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="silicon (page does not exist)">silicon</a> materials occurred during the war to develop detectors of consistent quality.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris90_7-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris90-7">[7</a>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_transistors">Early transistors</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=semiconductor&action=edit&section=3" title="Edit section: Early transistors">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<dl><dd><i>Main article: <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_transistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="History of the transistor (page does not exist)">History of the transistor</a></i></dd></dl>
<p><br/>
Detector and power rectifiers could not amplify a signal. Many efforts were made to develop a solid-state amplifier and were successful in developing a device called the <a href="/w/index.php?title=point_contact_transistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="point contact transistor (page does not exist)">point contact transistor</a> which could amplify 20db or more.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris90_7-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris90-7">[7</a>]</sup> In 1922 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oleg_Losev&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Oleg Losev (page does not exist)">Oleg Losev</a> developed two-terminal, <a href="/w/index.php?title=negative_resistance&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="negative resistance (page does not exist)">negative resistance</a> amplifiers for radio, and he perished in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Siege_of_Leningrad&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Siege of Leningrad (page does not exist)">Siege of Leningrad</a> after successful completion. In 1926 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Julius_Edgar_Lilienfeld&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Julius Edgar Lilienfeld (page does not exist)">Julius Edgar Lilienfeld</a> patented a device resembling a <a href="/wiki/field-effect_transistor" title="field-effect transistor">field-effect transistor</a>, but it was not practical. R. Hilsch and R. W. Pohl in 1938 demonstrated a solid-state amplifier using a structure resembling the control grid of a vacuum tube; although the device displayed power gain, it had a <a href="/w/index.php?title=cut-off_frequency&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="cut-off frequency (page does not exist)">cut-off frequency</a> of one cycle per second, too low for any practical applications, but an effective application of the available theory.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris90_7-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris90-7">[7</a>]</sup> At <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bell_Labs&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Bell Labs (page does not exist)">Bell Labs</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Shockley&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="William Shockley (page does not exist)">William Shockley</a> and A. Holden started investigating solid-state amplifiers in 1938. The first p–n junction in silicon was observed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russell_Ohl&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Russell Ohl (page does not exist)">Russell Ohl</a> about 1941, when a specimen was found to be light-sensitive, with a sharp boundary between p-type impurity at one end and n-type at the other. A slice cut from the specimen at the p–n boundary developed a voltage when exposed to light.
</p><p>The first working <a href="/w/index.php?title=transistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="transistor (page does not exist)">transistor</a> was a <a href="/w/index.php?title=point-contact_transistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="point-contact transistor (page does not exist)">point-contact transistor</a> invented by <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Bardeen&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="John Bardeen (page does not exist)">John Bardeen</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walter_Houser_Brattain&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Walter Houser Brattain (page does not exist)">Walter Houser Brattain</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Shockley&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="William Shockley (page does not exist)">William Shockley</a> at Bell Labs in 1947. Shockley had earlier theorized a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Field-effect_transistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Field-effect transistor (page does not exist)">field-effect amplifier</a> made from germanium and silicon, but he failed to build such a working device, before eventually using germanium to invent the point-contact transistor.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10</a>]</sup> In France, during the war, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Herbert_Matar%C3%A9&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Herbert Mataré (page does not exist)">Herbert Mataré</a> had observed amplification between adjacent point contacts on a germanium base. After the war, Mataré's group announced their "Transistron" amplifier only shortly after Bell Labs announced the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=transistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="transistor (page does not exist)">transistor</a>".
</p><p>In 1954, <a href="/w/index.php?title=physical_chemist&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="physical chemist (page does not exist)">physical chemist</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Morris_Tanenbaum&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Morris Tanenbaum (page does not exist)">Morris Tanenbaum</a> fabricated the first silicon <a href="/w/index.php?title=junction_transistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="junction transistor (page does not exist)">junction transistor</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bell_Labs&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Bell Labs (page does not exist)">Bell Labs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11</a>]</sup> However, early <a href="/w/index.php?title=junction_transistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="junction transistor (page does not exist)">junction transistors</a> were relatively bulky devices that were difficult to manufacture on a <a href="/w/index.php?title=mass-production&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="mass-production (page does not exist)">mass-production</a> basis, which limited them to a number of specialised applications.<sup id="cite_ref-Moskowitz_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moskowitz-12">[12</a>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Silicon_semiconductors">Silicon semiconductors</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=semiconductor&action=edit&section=4" title="Edit section: Silicon semiconductors">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<dl><dd><i>Main articles: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Silicon&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Silicon (page does not exist)">Silicon</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Silicon_Age&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Silicon Age (page does not exist)">Silicon Age</a></i></dd></dl>
<dl><dd><i>See also: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Surface_passivation&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Surface passivation (page does not exist)">Surface passivation</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thermal_oxidation&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Thermal oxidation (page does not exist)">Thermal oxidation</a></i></dd></dl>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Atalla1963.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Atalla1963.png/250px-Atalla1963.png" width="150" height="197" class="thumbimage" srcset="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Atalla1963.png/330px-Atalla1963.png 2x"/></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Atalla1963.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mohamed_Atalla&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Mohamed Atalla (page does not exist)">Mohamed Atalla</a> invented the <a href="/w/index.php?title=surface_passivation&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="surface passivation (page does not exist)">surface passivation</a> process in 1957, <a href="/wiki/MOSFET" class="mw-redirect" title="MOSFET">MOSFET</a> in 1959, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=MOS_integrated_circuit&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="MOS integrated circuit (page does not exist)">MOS integrated circuit</a> chip in 1960.</div></div></div>
<p>The first <a href="/w/index.php?title=silicon&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="silicon (page does not exist)">silicon</a> semiconductor device was a silicon radio crystal detector, developed by American engineer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenleaf_Whittier_Pickard&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenleaf Whittier Pickard (page does not exist)">Greenleaf Whittier Pickard</a> in 1906.<sup id="cite_ref-computerhistory-1901_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-computerhistory-1901-9">[9</a>]</sup> In 1940, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russell_Ohl&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Russell Ohl (page does not exist)">Russell Ohl</a> discovered the <a href="/w/index.php?title=p-n_junction&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="p-n junction (page does not exist)">p-n junction</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=photovoltaic_effect&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="photovoltaic effect (page does not exist)">photovoltaic effects</a> in silicon. In 1941, techniques for producing high-purity <a href="/w/index.php?title=germanium&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="germanium (page does not exist)">germanium</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=silicon_crystal&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="silicon crystal (page does not exist)">silicon crystals</a> were developed for <a href="/w/index.php?title=radar&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="radar (page does not exist)">radar</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=microwave&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="microwave (page does not exist)">microwave</a> detectors during <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_II&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="World War II (page does not exist)">World War II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-computerhistory-timeline_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-computerhistory-timeline-8">[8</a>]</sup> In 1955, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carl_Frosch&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Carl Frosch (page does not exist)">Carl Frosch</a> and Lincoln Derick at Bell Labs accidentally discovered that <a href="/w/index.php?title=silicon_dioxide&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="silicon dioxide (page does not exist)">silicon dioxide</a> (SiO<sub>2</sub>) could be grown on silicon,<sup id="cite_ref-Bassett22_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bassett22-13">[13</a>]</sup> and they later proposed this could mask silicon surfaces during <a href="/w/index.php?title=diffusion_processes&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="diffusion processes (page does not exist)">diffusion processes</a> in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-Saxena_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Saxena-14">[14</a>]</sup>
</p><p>In the early years of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=semiconductor_industry&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="semiconductor industry (page does not exist)">semiconductor industry</a>, up until the late 1950s, germanium was the dominant semiconductor material for transistors and other semiconductor devices, rather than silicon. Germanium was initially considered the more effective semiconductor material, as it was able to demonstrate better performance due to higher <a href="/wiki/carrier_mobility" title="carrier mobility">carrier mobility</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dabrowski6_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dabrowski6-15">[15</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-Heywang_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heywang-16">[16</a>]</sup> The relative lack of performance in early silicon semiconductors was due to <a href="/w/index.php?title=electrical_conductivity&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="electrical conductivity (page does not exist)">electrical conductivity</a> being limited by unstable <a href="/w/index.php?title=Quantum_mechanics&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Quantum mechanics (page does not exist)">quantum</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=surface_states&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="surface states (page does not exist)">surface states</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Feldman_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Feldman-17">[17</a>]</sup> where <a href="/w/index.php?title=electrons&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="electrons (page does not exist)">electrons</a> are trapped at the surface, due to <a href="/w/index.php?title=dangling_bonds&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="dangling bonds (page does not exist)">dangling bonds</a> that occur because <a href="/w/index.php?title=unsaturated_bond&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="unsaturated bond (page does not exist)">unsaturated bonds</a> are present at the surface.<sup id="cite_ref-Kooi_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kooi-18">[18</a>]</sup> This prevented <a href="/w/index.php?title=electricity&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="electricity (page does not exist)">electricity</a> from reliably penetrating the surface to reach the semiconducting silicon layer.<sup id="cite_ref-atalla_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-atalla-19">[19</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-kahng_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kahng-20">[20</a>]</sup>
</p><p>A breakthrough in silicon semiconductor technology came with the work of Egyptian engineer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mohamed_Atalla&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Mohamed Atalla (page does not exist)">Mohamed Atalla</a>, who developed the process of <a href="/w/index.php?title=surface_passivation&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="surface passivation (page does not exist)">surface passivation</a> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=thermal_oxidation&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="thermal oxidation (page does not exist)">thermal oxidation</a> at Bell Labs in the late 1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-Kooi_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kooi-18">[18</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-Black_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Black-21">[21</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-Heywang_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heywang-16">[16</a>]</sup> He discovered that the formation of a thermally grown silicon dioxide layer greatly reduced the concentration of <a href="/w/index.php?title=electronic_state&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="electronic state (page does not exist)">electronic states</a> at the silicon surface,<sup id="cite_ref-Black_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Black-21">[21</a>]</sup> and that silicon oxide layers could be used to electrically stabilize silicon surfaces.<sup id="cite_ref-Lecuyer_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lecuyer-22">[22</a>]</sup> Atalla first published his findings in Bell memos during 1957, and then demonstrated it in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-Lojek_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lojek-23">[23</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bassett46_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bassett46-24">[24</a>]</sup> This was the first demonstration to show that high-quality silicon dioxide insulator films could be grown thermally on the silicon surface to protect the underlying silicon p-n junction <a href="/w/index.php?title=diodes&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="diodes (page does not exist)">diodes</a> and transistors.<sup id="cite_ref-Saxena_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Saxena-14">[14</a>]</sup> Atalla's surface passivation process enabled silicon to surpass the conductivity and performance of germanium, and led to silicon replacing germanium as the dominant semiconductor material.<sup id="cite_ref-Heywang_16-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heywang-16">[16</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-Feldman_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Feldman-17">[17</a>]</sup> Atalla's surface passivation process is considered the most important advance in silicon semiconductor technology, paving the way for the mass-production of silicon semiconductor devices.<sup id="cite_ref-Sah_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sah-25">[25</a>]</sup> By the mid-1960s, Atalla's process for oxidized silicon surfaces was used to fabricate virtually all integrated circuits and silicon devices.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26</a>]</sup> Surface passivation by thermal oxidation remains a key feature of silicon semiconductor technology.<sup id="cite_ref-sciencedirect_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sciencedirect-27">[27</a>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="MOS_transistor">MOS transistor</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=semiconductor&action=edit&section=5" title="Edit section: MOS transistor">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<dl><dd><i>Main article: <a href="/wiki/MOSFET" class="mw-redirect" title="MOSFET">MOSFET</a></i></dd></dl>
<dl><dd><i>Further information: <a href="/w/index.php?title=MOS_integrated_circuit&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="MOS integrated circuit (page does not exist)">MOS integrated circuit</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=MOS_revolution&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="MOS revolution (page does not exist)">MOS revolution</a></i></dd></dl>
<dl><dd><i>See also: <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_semiconductor_scale_examples&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="List of semiconductor scale examples (page does not exist)">List of semiconductor scale examples</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Transistor_count&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Transistor count (page does not exist)">Transistor count</a></i></dd></dl>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="https://computer.fandom.com/wiki/File:MOSFET_Structure.png"><img alt="" src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/MOSFET_Structure.png/330px-MOSFET_Structure.png" width="300" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/MOSFET_Structure.png/500px-MOSFET_Structure.png 1.5x, https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/MOSFET_Structure.png/613px-MOSFET_Structure.png 2x"/></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:MOSFET_Structure.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/MOSFET" class="mw-redirect" title="MOSFET">MOSFET</a> (MOS transistor) was invented by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mohamed_Atalla&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Mohamed Atalla (page does not exist)">Mohamed Atalla</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dawon_Kahng&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Dawon Kahng (page does not exist)">Dawon Kahng</a> in 1959.</div></div></div>
<p>In the late 1950s, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mohamed_Atalla&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Mohamed Atalla (page does not exist)">Mohamed Atalla</a> utilized his <a href="/w/index.php?title=surface_passivation&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="surface passivation (page does not exist)">surface passivation</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=thermal_oxidation&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="thermal oxidation (page does not exist)">thermal oxidation</a> methods to develop the <a href="/wiki/metal%E2%80%93oxide%E2%80%93semiconductor" class="mw-redirect" title="metal–oxide–semiconductor">metal–oxide–semiconductor</a> (MOS) process, which he proposed could be used to build the first working silicon field-effect transistor.<sup id="cite_ref-atalla_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-atalla-19">[19</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-kahng_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kahng-20">[20</a>]</sup> This led to the invention of the <a href="/wiki/MOSFET" class="mw-redirect" title="MOSFET">MOSFET</a> (MOS field-effect transistor) by Mohamed Atalla and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dawon_Kahng&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Dawon Kahng (page does not exist)">Dawon Kahng</a> in 1959.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lojek_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lojek-23">[23</a>]</sup> It was the first truly compact transistor that could be miniaturised and mass-produced for a wide range of uses,<sup id="cite_ref-Moskowitz_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moskowitz-12">[12</a>]</sup> With its <a href="/w/index.php?title=MOSFET_scaling&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="MOSFET scaling (page does not exist)">scalability</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29</a>]</sup> and much lower power consumption and higher density than <a href="/w/index.php?title=bipolar_junction_transistor&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="bipolar junction transistor (page does not exist)">bipolar junction transistors</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30</a>]</sup> the MOSFET became the most common type of transistor in computers, electronics,<sup id="cite_ref-kahng_20-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kahng-20">[20</a>]</sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=communications_technology&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="communications technology (page does not exist)">communications technology</a> such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=smartphones&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="smartphones (page does not exist)">smartphones</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-uspto_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uspto-31">[31</a>]</sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=US_Patent_and_Trademark_Office&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="US Patent and Trademark Office (page does not exist)">US Patent and Trademark Office</a> calls the MOSFET a "groundbreaking invention that transformed life and culture around the world".<sup id="cite_ref-uspto_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uspto-31">[31</a>]</sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/CMOS" class="mw-redirect" title="CMOS">CMOS</a> (complementary MOS) process was developed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chih-Tang_Sah&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Chih-Tang Sah (page does not exist)">Chih-Tang Sah</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frank_Wanlass&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Frank Wanlass (page does not exist)">Frank Wanlass</a> at <a href="/wiki/Fairchild_Semiconductor" class="mw-redirect" title="Fairchild Semiconductor">Fairchild Semiconductor</a> in 1963.<sup id="cite_ref-computerhistory1963_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-computerhistory1963-32">[32</a>]</sup> The first report of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=floating-gate_MOSFET&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="floating-gate MOSFET (page does not exist)">floating-gate MOSFET</a> was made by Dawon Kahng and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Sze&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Simon Sze (page does not exist)">Simon Sze</a> in 1967.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33</a>]</sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=FinFET&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="FinFET (page does not exist)">FinFET</a> (fin field-effect transistor), a type of 3D <a href="/w/index.php?title=Multigate_device&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Multigate device (page does not exist)">multi-gate</a> MOSFET, was developed by Digh Hisamoto and his team of researchers at <a href="/wiki/Hitachi" class="mw-redirect" title="Hitachi">Hitachi Central Research Laboratory</a> in 1989.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34</a>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35</a>]</sup>
</p>
